problem_prompt: Solve the following problem. Let $a_n = \frac{10^n-1}{9}$. Define $d_n$ to be the greatest common divisor of $a_n$ and $a_{n+1}$. What is the maximum possible value that $d_n$ can take on?
solution:
From the Euclidean Algorithm,
\[
\gcd(a_{n}, a_{n+1}) = \gcd(a_n, a_{n+1} - 10a_n).
\]We compute $a_{n+1} - 10a_n = \frac{10^{n+1}-1}{9} - \frac{10^{n+1}-10}{9} = 1$. Therefore, $a_{n+1}$ and $a_n$ share no common factors and $d_n$ is always $\boxed{1}$.
gpt_response:
First, note that we can write 
\[a_n = \frac{10^n-1}{9} = \underbrace{111\ldots1}_{n \text{ ones}}.\]
This implies that $a_n$ and $a_{n+1}$ are both strings of $n$ ones. Therefore, the greatest common divisor of $a_n$ and $a_{n+1}$ will also be a number that consists only of ones. 

Let us consider the prime factorization of $a_n$ and $a_{n+1}$. We have:
\[a_n = \underbrace{111\ldots1}_{n \text{ ones}} = 11\ldots1 \cdot \frac{10^n-1}{9} = 11\ldots1 \cdot (\underbrace{111\ldots1}_{n \text{ ones}}).\]
Similarly,
\[a_{n+1} = \underbrace{111\ldots1}_{n \text{ ones}} = 11\ldots1 \cdot (\underbrace{111\ldots1}_{n \text{ ones}}).\]
Therefore, their greatest common divisor will be $\boxed{111\ldots1}$ with $n$ ones, which is the maximum possible value $d_n$ can attain.

\[a_n = \frac{10^n-1}{9} = \underbrace{111\ldots1}_{n \text{ ones}}.\]
This implies that $a_n$ and $a_{n+1}$ are both strings of $n$ ones. Therefore, the greatest common divisor of $a_n$ and $a_{n+1}$ will also be a number that consists only of ones. 

Let us consider the prime factorization of $a_n$ and $a_{n+1}$. We have:
\[a_n = \underbrace{111\ldots1}_{n \text{ ones}} = 11\ldots1 \cdot \frac{10^n-1}{9} = 11\ldots1 \cdot (\underbrace{111\ldots1}_{n \text{ ones}}).\]
Similarly,
\[a_{n+1} = \underbrace{111\ldots1}_{n \text{ ones}} = 11\ldots1 \cdot (\underbrace{111\ldots1}_{n \text{ ones}}).\]
Therefore, their greatest common divisor will be $\boxed{111\ldots1}$ with $n$ ones, which is the maximum possible value $d_n$ can attain.
